review.title: Multiattribute Auctions Based on Generalized Additive Independence
review.abstract: We develop multiattribute auctions that accommodate generalized additive independent (GAI) preferences. We propose an iterative auction mechanism that maintains prices on potentially overlapping GAI clusters of attributes, thus decreases elicitation and computational burden, and creates an open competition among suppliers over a multidimensional domain. Most significantly, the auction is guaranteed to achieve surplus which approximates optimal welfare up to a small additive factor, under reasonable equilibrium strategies of traders. The main departure of GAI auctions from previous literature is to accommodate non-additive trader preferences, hence allowing traders to condition their evaluation of specific attributes on the value of other attributes. At the same time, the GAI structure supports a compact representation of prices, enabling a tractable auction process. We perform a simulation study, demonstrating and quantifying the significant efficiency advantage of more expressive preference modeling. We draw random GAI-structured utility functions with various internal structures, generate additive functions that approximate the GAI utility, and compare the performance of the auctions using the two representations. We find that allowing traders to express existing dependencies among attributes improves the economic efficiency of multiattribute auctions.

sections.heading: 7. Experimental Design
sections.text: The main idea behind GAI auctions is to improve efficiency over auctions where additivity is assumed when preferences are not additive. However, the theoretical efficiency guarantee of GAI auctions depends (when set ") on e, the connectivity parameter of the GAI tree. This suggests a trade-off: complex models represent the true benefit more accurately, but can increase approximation errors due to higher connectivity. An obvious question is whether more accurate preference modeling is actually more efficient, and in particular whether GAI auctions are more efficient than addictive auctions, since the preferences are not addictive. To answer the question experimentally, we assume that the buyer's preferences have a certain GAI structure and compare the performance of GAI auctions that model this structure with the performance of auctions that are limited to addictive representation. For the latter, we will use an example of the GAI structure, which is the price structure.

sections.heading: 8.2 Computational Analysis
sections.text: These algorithms have been proposed and applied for combinatorial optimization problems before (Dechter, 1997; Nilsson, 1998), so the calculation time required to process a round is not of particular interest for this work. Instead, we focus on the number of rounds that the auction requires. We tested the number of rounds required by GAI and AP auctions under completely random and FOPI preferences, varying three of the parameters: the size of the largest GAI element), e (connectivity) and δ.The complexity in terms of the number of rounds is shown in Figure 4a (in relation to Figure 4b) and Figure 4b (in relation to the number of elements).We observe that under FOPI the GAI auction takes much longer, compared to the case of random preferences. The reason is that under FOPI the sellers and the preferences of the buyer in general can be regarded as opposites: fixed prices and fixed points.

sections.heading: 8.3 Information Revelation
sections.text: A key difference between the mechanism proposed here and most previous publications is the extent to which the purchaser must disclose preference information. Therefore, another experimental question is whether this mechanism significantly reduces the total amount of information disclosed by the purchaser. PK investigates information that both the purchaser and the seller disclose under an additivity assumption. If the utility function is additive, the amount of information disclosed can be measured in relation to the limitations of linear weight distribution. Sellers can infer the weight proportions of the purchaser, and the amount of information hidden from them is represented by the fraction of the simplicity that meets these limitations. This simple analysis is not possible for GAI companies. We propose an alternative that is geared to the type of information disclosed by the GAI auctions.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusions
sections.text: We propose a novel exploitation of the preference structure of GAI auctions, where GAI representation can be constructed from relatively simple statements about willingness to pay, and develop an iterative auction mechanism based directly on decomposition. Our auction mechanism generalizes the preference modeling used by Parkes and Kalagnanam (2005), while essentially retaining their information explanatory properties. It allows for a number of trade-offs between the accuracy of the preference representation and the computational complexity of the auction, as well as the trade-off between purchaser information disclosure and the number of rounds required for convergence. We conducted a simulation study of our proposed multi-attribute auctions, compared to a mechanism that presupposes additive preferences. The study validated the usefulness of GAI auctions when preferences are not additive, but GAI significant, and we allowed the overall efficiency classes for the efficiency.
